column1: 2020-12-15 09:00:00#science#Jupiter and Saturn join in the night sky in 'great conjunction.' Here's how you can see it#https://ca.news.yahoo.com/keep-eye-sky-jupiter-saturn-090000218.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/BYbzdkT5bNmchc1eDV3HJg--~B/aD0zNDk7dz02MjA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/cbc.ca/77df62a3c6f3697ae22bbb935a869ce2#sw#0.743#ca.news.yahoo.com#"If you have a keen eye
column2: you may have noticed two fairly bright objects resembling stars low in the western sky after sunset inching closer together over the past month.  But those aren't stars: they're two planets
column3: Jupiter and Saturn.  On Dec.  21 — the day of the winter solstice — the two will be so close together they'll almost seem to touch. Jupiter and Saturn — the largest planets in our solar system — have been visible in the sky since spring
column4: with Jupiter being the brighter of the two; it is also the second-brightest planet in the sky after Venus.  In the summer
column5: the pair were high in the south
column6: but over the past few months
column7: they've been getting closer and closer
column8: and lower in the southwestern sky. Astronomers call close pairings of astronomical objects conjunctions.  And this conjunction of the two planets is the closest since 1623
column9: making it a ""great conjunction"" — though that event wasn't visible as they were too close to the sun. The last time the pair were observed to be this close was in 1226
column10: almost 800 years ago
column11: a time when Ghengis Khan's rule was coming to an end. How to find themAstronomers measure the distance between two objects in the sky using degrees.  Right now
column12: the two planets are roughly 0. 7 degrees apart.  But on Dec.  21
column13: they will be a mere 1/10th of a degree apart. You can measure their close approach over the coming days with your own fingers.  Using your pinky finger held at arm's length is a rough measure of one degree of separation.  To find the two planets
column14: you'll need a good view of the southwestern horizon shortly after sunset.  And while you don't need any equipment to view it
column15: if you have a pair of binoculars
column16: you'll be able to tease them apart.  Viewers with telescopes will get a rare chance to capture the pair in a single field of view. December isn't exactly a great time to catch astronomical events as it is one of the cloudiest months of the year across the country.  So if you can't watch the event on Dec.  21
column17: there are some options to see it online. If the skies are clear in Toronto
column18: York University's Allan I.  Carswell Observatory will host a live online event.  In Arizona
column19: where there's a better chance of clear skies
column20: the historic Lowell Observatory will also be hosting a live online event. And while it's been quite some time since the planets were this close
column21: conjunctions do occur every 20 years this century.  But this will be the closest the pair will get for the next 60 years
column22: so try to catch it if you can. "##https://ca.news.yahoo.com/keep-eye-sky-jupiter-saturn-090000218.html

column1: 2020-12-10 22:15:00#world#106 House Republicans support suit challenging blue states' election results - including 16 re-elected on the same ballots#https://news.yahoo.com/106-house-republicans-support-suit-221500955.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/vAuq_C.RyqBeh2DUyw5eLg--~B/aD01NjA7dz04NDA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_week_574/7f97fa0b951c655dd1622371eca1c244#sw#0.5106#news.yahoo.com#"Texas' attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election is wracked with contradictions. On Tuesday
column2: Texas' attorney general filed a lawsuit asking the Supreme Court to overturn the election results in Georgia
column3: Michigan
column4: Pennsylvania
column5: and Wisconsin
column6: alleging the states improperly manipulated voting rules.  Seventeen red states have since filed in support of the suit
column7: even though Texas and several other states had implemented the same mail-in and early-voting rules by the same methods.  And in a further paradox on Thursday
column8: 106 GOP House members also joined Texas' suit as amici curiae
column9: despite the fact that many of them had been re-elected on the same ballots. Georgia
column10: Michigan
column11: Pennsylvania
column12: and Wisconsin flipped from electing President Trump in the 2016 election to going for President-elect Joe Biden in 2020.  But those states all managed to elect and re-elect several Republican congressmembers -- 16 of whom filed in support of the suit Thursday -- using the exact same voting rules that also elected Biden. Not every congressional Republican is onboard with the Texas suit.  Sen.  Ben Sasse (R-Neb. ) suggested Texas' attorney general was ""begging for a pardon"" and ""filed a PR stunt rather than a lawsuit
column13: while three members of the Texas delegation had their doubts.  Sen.  Ted Cruz (R-Texas) has meanwhile offered to present the case for Trump in front of the Supreme Court.  > Texas lawmakers on the Texas lawsuit: > Sen.  John Cornyn: ""I frankly struggle to understand the legal theory of it. "" > Rep.  Kay Granger: ""I'm not supporting it. . . It's a distraction. "" > Rep.  Chip Roy: ""I believe the case itself represents a dangerous violation of federalism. ""> > -- Kaitlan Collins (@kaitlancollins) December 10
column14: 2020More stories from theweek. com 7 criminally funny cartoons about Trump's potential pardon spree Why Trump supporters won't accept election results The GOP is driving itself mad"##https://news.yahoo.com/106-house-republicans-support-suit-221500955.html

column2: or ''radiations
column3: '' a model called ''creative destruction. '' However

column1: 2020-12-08 17:59:50#entertainment#5 Best Looks From the 2020 MTV Movie & TV Awards: Greatest of All Time#https://www.msn.com/en-us/entertainment/awards/5-best-looks-from-the-2020-mtv-movie-tv-awards-greatest-of-all-time/ss-BB1bI4JH?li=BBnb2gh#https://www.msn.com/en-us/entertainment/awards/5-best-looks-from-the-2020-mtv-movie-tv-awards-greatest-of-all-time/ss-BB1bI4JH?li=BBnb2gh#sw#0.9081#www.msn.com#Another surprisingly stylish red carpet! The 2020 MTV Movie & TV Awards: Greatest of All Time took place on Sunday
column2: December 6
column3: and stars slayed in some seriously sexy looks.  But there were five celebs in particular that stood out.  VMAs 2020 Red Carpet Fashion: See the Stars’ Style Read article Due to the COVID-19 pandemic
column4: awards shows have had to reimagine their usual formulas for red carpets
column5: host’s monologues
column6: speeches and so-forth in order to follow safety precautions.  So in place of the traditional MTV Movie & TV Awards
column7: this year’s special event celebrated all kinds of pop cultural touchstones from the ‘80s until now! Throughout the 90-minute special
column8: the biggest and best moments in TV and Movie history were honored.  From Jason Segel and Kristen Bell’s heartbreaking breakup in Forgetting Sarah Marshall to Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore as a Dynamic Duo in 50 First Dates
column9: this unconventional awards show was a chance to reminisce.  MTV EMAs 2020: See the Best Looks From the Red Carpet Read article But it wasn’t just the nostalgia that we loved.  We also couldn’t take our eyes off the sexy fashion.  Vanessa Hudgens hosted the affair
column10: taking this opportunity as a chance to whip out her chicest looks.  It was her red carpet ensemble that really did it for Us
column11: though.  With its simple silhouette
column12: sleek fabric and standout accessories
column13: the whole thing was a total knockout.  Lily Collins also went for something that was equal parts sophisticated and sexy.  The Emily in Paris star donned a latex Saint Laurent by Anthony Vaccarello dress that hugged her figure.  She combined this outfit with a sultry makeup look created by makeup artist Fiona Stiles using Lancôme products.  “I wanted to create a very chic
column14: sophisticated look for Lily for the MTV Awards
column15: ” Styles said.  “Her Saint Laurent dress was very cool and edgy and I wanted to compliment that with a refined
column16: elegant look. ” So she gave her a smokey eye
column17: killer brows and a mauve lip that’s just to die for.  Keep scrolling to see our five favorite looks from the MTV awards show.  Listen on Spotify to Get Tressed With Us to get the details of every hair love affair in Hollywood
column18: from the hits and misses on the red carpet to your favorite celebrities’ street style ‘dos (and don’ts!)##https://www.msn.com/en-us/entertainment/awards/5-best-looks-from-the-2020-mtv-movie-tv-awards-greatest-of-all-time/ss-BB1bI4JH?li=BBnb2gh

column5: most issues were long-ago fixed and I had no problems when playing it a year or so after release. The game eventually received a bunch of DLC

column7: along with dozens and dozens of different Batsuits.  Two of those were previously pretty obscure
column8: having been linked to players who had completed the game and connected to a WBPlay account.  WBPlay seems to have been a badly thought-through service

column1: 2020-11-28 20:41:25#entertainment#Glenn Close Says Gwyneth Paltrow’s ‘Shakespeare in Love’ Oscar Win ‘Doesn’t Make Sense’#https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/glenn-close-says-gwyneth-paltrow-204125899.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/7yg5tgNoL2_tTg7vaw6GGQ--~B/aD00MDA7dz02MTg7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/thewrap.com/ab597d795344df8bdb5490f6db6cea3d#sw#0.5859#www.yahoo.com#Glenn Close said this week that Gwyneth Paltrow’s 1998 “Best Actress” Oscar for “Shakespeare in Love” just “doesn’t make sense. ”Close was on ABC News’ “Popcorn with Peter Travers” to promote her new Netflix film
column2: “Hillbilly Elegy
column3: ” when she shared her distaste for awards on the grounds that she can’t justify comparing artists’ works. “I’ve never understood how you could honestly compare performances.  I remember the year Gwyneth Paltrow won over that incredible actress who was in ‘Central Station
column4: '” she said
column5: referring to Fernanda Montenegro.  Paltrow and Montenegro were also up against Cate Blanchett (for “Elizabeth”)
column6: Meryl Streep (for “One True Thing”) and Emily Watson (for “Hilary and Jackie”). Also Read: Critics Call Ron Howard's 'Hillbilly Elegy' 'Laughably Horrendous
column7: ' 'Worst Film of His Career'Close went on
column8: “I thought
column9: ‘What?’ It’s like
column10: it doesn’t make sense
column11: so I think who wins has a lot of things to do with how things have been
column12: whether it has traction or whatever.  Publicity
column13: how much money did they have to put it out in front of everybody’s sight? So
column14: you know
column15: I have to be philosophical about it. ”The “they” in question here is Harvey Weinstein’s production company
column16: which was behind “Shakespeare in Love. ” The film also won “Best Picture” at that year’s awards ceremony. Close herself has been nominated for seven Oscars
column17: giving her the title of the most-nominated actress without a single win.  Travers brought up the industry surprise at her failure to net a win so far
column18: calling her “gracious” about the whole thing. He asked
column19: “How do you handle things like that?” The conversation led to her sharing her thoughts
column20: including her conviction that even to be nominated by her peers is “as good as it gets. ”Watch the interview above
column21: via ABC News. Read original story Glenn Close Says Gwyneth Paltrow’s ‘Shakespeare in Love’ Oscar Win ‘Doesn’t Make Sense’ At TheWrap##https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/glenn-close-says-gwyneth-paltrow-204125899.html

2020-11-26 17:12:01#entertainment#‘Superintelligence’ Film Review: Melissa McCarthy Is Humanity’s Last Hope in Superaverage Comedy#https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/superintelligence-film-review-melissa-mccarthy-171201300.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/Gw09IuVV5BvvrCcwlUL_cg--~B/aD00MDA7dz02MTg7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/thewrap.com/4fc34057831495be5d7941f2f52e31b2#sw#0.6597#www.yahoo.com#In “Superintelligence
column2: ” an average human being must convince a sentient AI program not to wipe out humanity.  Lucky for all of us
column3: the film “Superintelligence” is not entered as evidence that our continued existence is justified. It’s probably the most technically accomplished of the four theatrical features (to date) that Ben Falcone has directed with his wife Melissa McCarthy in the starring role
column4: but this partnership continues to be an imbalanced one
column5: at least in terms of results.  Their collaborations (which also include “Tammy
column7: ” and “Life of the Party”) constitute both her least-interesting movies as an actress and the entirety of his career as a filmmaker. As collaborators and co-stars
column8: they can be hilarious together — in performance; once he steps to the other side of the camera
column9: however
column10: the magic they create as a team seems to dissipate.  Neither of them gets much assistance from the screenplay by Steve Mallory (“The Boss”)
column11: which hinges the fate of mankind on a relationship between two people who
column12: to paraphrase the witch from “Into the Woods
column13: ” aren’t bad
column14: aren’t good
column15: they’re just nice. Watch Video: Melissa McCarthy Apologizes as HBO Max Nixes Donation to Group With Anti-LGBT History: 'We Blew It'Carol (McCarthy)
column16: our protagonist
column17: does want to do good in the world; since stepping down from her exec position at Yahoo
column18: she’s spent most of her time working for environmental and pet-rescue non-profits.  When the computer program inside an educational toy achieves awareness and becomes Superintelligence
column19: it selects Carol as the “most median” person alive to teach it about humanity; based on what it learns
column20: it will either save the human race
column21: subjugate it
column22: or wipe it out entirely. Superintelligence originally has a somewhat threatening voice that sends Carol into a panic
column23: so to calm her down
column24: it starts talking like James Corden.  That Corden himself is providing the voice could have been a mildly funny gag
column25: but the film presses that button over and over again
column26: to the point where characters have a conversation to remind each other about his Tony win for “One Man
column27: Two Guvnors. ” Rather than play on Corden’s ubiquity as a pitchman and TV talking head
column28: the film merely exacerbates his constant presence. Also Read: Melissa McCarthy
column29: Ben Falcone to Teach Online Classes to Support Groundlings TheaterAnyway
column30: Superintelligence buys Carol a Tesla (which it drives)
column31: overhauls her wardrobe
column32: gets her a swanky penthouse
column33: and establishes a two-billion-dollar foundation in her name — which is mostly forgotten by the movie and by Carol
column34: despite her philanthropic bent.  What the AI really wants is to observe her at her most human and vulnerable
column35: so it sends her off to mend fences with her ex
column36: George (Bobby Cannavale)
column37: a literature professor who is days away from taking off to Ireland on a fellowship. As the U. S.  government — aided by Carol’s buddy Dennis (Brian Tyree Henry)
column38: a Microsoft web-security expert — tries to take down the Superintelligence
column39: “Superintelligence” spends most of its time on the exceedingly uninteresting saga of whether or not Carol and George get back together.  Even when played by performers as dynamic as McCarthy and Cannavale
column40: these characters can’t manage one personality between them.  Altruism is a virtue
column41: but it’s not an identity
column42: and if we had a better idea who Carol was before meeting Superintelligence
column43: or perhaps more of a backstory behind her world-saving ways
column44: this movie might actually go somewhere or have something to say. Also Read: Melissa McCarthy Joins Hulu Limited Series 'Nine Perfect Strangers'McCarthy
column45: even in her most forgettable movies
column46: always manages to squeeze out some memorable moments
column47: whether she’s enduring a ridiculous job interview or enduring a series of ludicrous couture creations in a trying-on-clothes montage.  Henry finds little moments of absurdity throughout that make his scenes a highlight
column48: and you have to give at least a little credit to any film that casts Jean Smart as the President of the United States. Otherwise
column49: this is a production that is
column50: at best
